articles.headline: In Ordinary Lives, U.S. Sees the Work of Russian Agents
articles.snippet: They had lived for more than a decade in American cities and suburbs from Seattle to New York. But on Monday, prosecutors accused 11 people of being part of an espionage ring.
articles.abstract: They had lived for more than a decade in American cities and suburbs from Seattle to New York. But on Monday, prosecutors accused 11 people of being part of an espionage ring.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  They had lived for more than a decade in American cities and suburbs from Seattle to New York, where they seemed to be ordinary couples working ordinary jobs, chatting to the neighbors about schools and apologizing for noisy teenagers.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Suit Over Faulty Computers Highlights Dell’s Decline
articles.snippet: Documents show that Dell was aware of bad components in millions of computers sold from 2003 to 2005.
articles.abstract: Documents show that Dell was aware of bad components in millions of computers sold from 2003 to 2005.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the math department at the University of Texas noticed some of its Dell computers failing, Dell examined the machines. The company came up with an unusual reason for the computers’ demise: the school had overtaxed the machines by making them perform difficult math calculations.

articles.headline: Right-to-Know Law Gives India’s Poor a Lever
articles.snippet: The popular Right to Information law may not have made a big dent in corruption, but it has given a powerful tool to Indians by helping to resolve their complaints.
articles.abstract: The popular Right to Information law may not have made a big dent in corruption, but it has given a powerful tool to Indians by helping to resolve their complaints.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANTA, India  Chanchala Devi always wanted a house. Not a mud-and-stick hut, like her current home in this desolate village in the mineral-rich, corruption-corroded state of Jharkhand, but a proper brick-and-mortar house. When she heard that a government program for the poor would give her about $700 to build that house, she applied immediately.

articles.headline: In Ireland, a Picture of the High Cost of Austerity
articles.snippet: After adopting austerity measures two years ago, the economic downturn has only grown worse.
articles.abstract: After adopting austerity measures two years ago, the economic downturn has only grown worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN  As Europe’s major economies focus on belt-tightening, they are following the path of Ireland. But the once thriving nation is struggling, with no sign of a rapid turnaround in sight.

articles.headline: Fostering China’s Taste for Nuts
articles.snippet: Whether walnuts, pecans or almonds, American nuts are in strong demand in China, a turnabout in the usual export story.
articles.abstract: Whether walnuts, pecans or almonds, American nuts are in strong demand in China, a turnabout in the usual export story.
articles.lead_paragraph: How might the Chinese best like to snack on their almonds? Pickled with chili peppers? Wrapped in seaweed like sushi? Or perhaps mixed with donkey hide glue, a substance prized in traditional Chinese medicine?

articles.headline: Preparing for Next Big One
articles.snippet: Financial reform legislation is less important than how it is put in place.
articles.abstract: Financial reform legislation is less important than how it is put in place.
articles.lead_paragraph: The next Great Crash is coming. Guaranteed.

articles.headline: Spying Suspects Seemed Short on Secrets
articles.snippet: The suspected Russian spy ring rolled up by the F.B.I.  this week had everything it needed for world-class espionage, except actual secrets to send to Moscow.
articles.abstract: The suspected Russian spy ring rolled up by the F.B.I.  this week had everything it needed for world-class espionage, except actual secrets to send to Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The suspected Russian spy ring rolled up by the F.B.I. this week had everything it needed for world-class espionage: excellent training, cutting-edge gadgetry, deep knowledge of American culture and meticulously constructed cover stories.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Benjamin Weiser

articles.headline: U.S. Stocks Drop on New Jitters About Global Growth
articles.snippet: Stocks fell sharply as a decline in consumer confidence aggravated concern about the global economy and sent the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index to a low for the year.
articles.abstract: Stocks fell sharply as a decline in consumer confidence aggravated concern about the global economy and sent the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index to a low for the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: This looks like a long, hot summer for Wall Street.

articles.headline: Kagan Follows Precedent by Offering Few Opinions
articles.snippet: Elena Kagan deflected questions about her own views on gun rights and abortion during her Supreme Court confirmation hearings, instead describing Supreme Court precedents.
articles.abstract: Elena Kagan deflected questions about her own views on gun rights and abortion during her Supreme Court confirmation hearings, instead describing Supreme Court precedents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Elena Kagan deflected questions about her own views on gun rights and abortion during her Supreme Court confirmation hearings on Tuesday, instead describing Supreme Court precedents. She declined to say whether terrorism suspects must be warned of the right to remain silent, saying the issue was “quite likely to get to the courts.”
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
